specJson.name: brightics.function.textanalytics$lda3
specJson.label: Latent Dirichlet Allocation
specJson.description:
The generated topic model is then used for classifying the documents based on topics automatically chosen by the model. To choose topics, this function adapts Gibbs sampling.

When we have a text document dataset to analyze, we need to do pre-process for the dataset. In general, we split texts into terms (words), build a vocabulary that only consider the top max_features ordered by term frequency across the corpus, and then remove (1) terms that have a document frequency strictly higher than 0.95 (2) terms that have a document frequency strictly lower than counts 2 (3) a built-in stopwords list for English is used.  

This pre-processing should be performed carefully to get better results. This function performs this pre-processing with default setting we mentioned above.

Also, choosing the number of topics based on the dataset is very important. It could be possible for you to choose either randomly till you can get your desired results or thoroughly based on knowledge of the given text. Increasing number of iterations for running LDA model would give you stable results.

Reference: 
+ <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Latent_Dirichlet_allocation>
+ "Online Learning for Latent Dirichlet Allocation", Matthew D. Hoffman, David M. Blei, Francis Bach, 2010

params.label: Input Column
params.description: Text data column to select as an input.

params.label: Topic Column Name
params.description: Column name for topic modeling result.

params.label: Number of Vocabularies
params.description: The number of vocabularies that will be utilized to count their frequencies in the entire documents. It should be greater than or equal to two.

params.label: Number of Topics
params.description: The number of topics that will be contained in the entire documents. It should be greater than or equal to two.

params.label: Number of Terminologies
params.description: Maximum number of terminologies you want to show for particular topics. It should be greater than or equal to two. Terminology number should be less than or equal to vocabulary size also.

params.label: Iterations
params.description: Maximum number of iterations you want to run your model. It should be at least one.

params.label: Learning Method
params.description: Method used to update parameters for topic word distribution. In each EM(Expectation Maximization) update, `Online` uses mini-batch of training data to update the parameters for topic word distribution variable incrementally. `Batch` uses all training data in each EM update. Old parameters for topic word distribution will be overwritten in each iteration.

params.label: Learning Offset
params.description: A (positive) parameter that downweights early iterations in online learning. It should be greater than 1.0.

params.label: Seed
params.description: Random seed. Use the same seed in order to reproduce the same results.

specJson.summary: This function builds a topic model for text documents with LDA.

md: # Latent Dirichlet Allocation This function builds a topic model for text documents with LDA. ## Description The generated topic model is then used for classifying the documents based on topics automatically chosen by the model. To choose topics, this function adapts Gibbs sampling. When we have a text document dataset to analyze, we need to do pre-process for the dataset. In general, we split texts into terms (words), build a vocabulary that only consider the top max_features ordered by term frequency across the corpus, and then remove (1) terms that have a document frequency strictly higher than 0.95 (2) terms that have a document frequency strictly lower than counts 2 (3) a built-in stopwords list for English is used. This pre-processing should be performed carefully to get better results. This function performs this pre-processing with default setting we mentioned above. Also, choosing the number of topics based on the dataset is very important. It could be possible for you to choose either randomly till you can get your desired results or thoroughly based on knowledge of the given text. Increasing number of iterations for running LDA model would give you stable results. Reference + + "Online Learning for Latent Dirichlet Allocation", Matthew D. Hoffman, David M. Blei, Francis Bach, 2010 ## Properties ### VA #### INPUT 1. **table***: (Table) Data including text documents. #### OUTPUT 1. **out_table**: (Table) Table including topic modeling result. #### PARAMETER 1. **Input Column***: Text data column to select as an input. Data type should be a string or list of string. 2. **Topic Column Name**: Column name for topic modeling result. 3. **Number of Vocabularies**: The number of vocabularies that will be utilized to count their frequencies in the entire documents. It should be greater than or equal to two. 4. **Number of Topics**: The number of topics that will be contained in the entire documents. It should be greater than or equal to two. 5. **Number of Terminologies**: Maximum number of terminologies you want to show for particular topics. It should be greater than or equal to two. Terminology number should be less than or equal to vocabulary size also. 6. **Iterations**: Maximum number of iterations you want to run your model. It should be at least one. 7. **Learning Method**: Method used to update parameters for topic word distribution. In each EM(Expectation Maximization) update, `Online` uses mini-batch of training data to update the parameters for topic word distribution variable incrementally. `Batch` uses all training data in each EM update. Old parameters for topic word distribution will be overwritten in each iteration. - Available Options : `Online`, `Batch` 8. **Seed**: Random seed. Use the same seed in order to reproduce the same results. 9. **Group By**: Columns to group by. ### Python #### USAGE ``` lda3(table, input_col, topic_name='topic', num_voca=1000, num_topic=3, num_topic_word=3, max_iter=20, learning_method='online', learning_offset=10., random_state=None, group_by=None) ``` #### INPUT 1. **table***: (Table) Data including text documents. #### OUTPUT 1. **out_table**: (Table) Table including topic modeling result. #### PARAMETER 1. **input_col***: Text data column to select as an input. * Type: *str* or *list[str]* 2. **topic_name**: Column name for topic modeling result. * Type: *str* * Default: topic 3. **num_voca**: The number of vocabularies that will be utilized to count their frequencies in the entire documents. It should be greater than or equal to two. * Type: *int* * Default / Range: 1000 (value >= 2) 4. **num_topic**: The number of topics that will be contained in the entire documents. It should be greater than or equal to two. * Type: *int* * Default / Range: 3 (value >= 2) 5. **num_topic_word**: Maximum number of terminologies you want to show for particular topics. It should be greater than or equal to two. Terminology number should be less than or equal to vocabulary size also. * Type: *int* * Default / Range: 3 (value >= 2) 6. **max_iter**: Maximum number of iterations you want to run your model. It should be at least one. * Type: *int* * Default / Range: 20 (value >= 1) 7. **learning_method**: Method used to update parameters for topic word distribution. In each EM(Expectation Maximization) update, `Online` uses mini-batch of training data to update the parameters for topic word distribution variable incrementally. `Batch` uses all training data in each EM update. Old parameters for topic word distribution will be overwritten in each iteration. * Type: *str* * Default / Range: online ( online | batch ) 8. **learning_offset**: A (positive) parameter that downweights early iterations in online learning. It should be greater than 1.0. * Type: *float* * Default / Range: 10.0 (value > 1.0) 9. **random_state**: Random seed. Use the same seed in order to reproduce the same results. * Type: *int* 10. **group_by**: Columns to group by. * Type: *list[str]* ## Example ### VA **[Related Tutorial]** **[Sample Model]** In this tutorial workflow, sample_LatentDirichletAllocation data is used to make topic model and get the result. The result includes assigned topic and contributiveness of each word to assigned topic. The parameter settings used in the function are shown below. ++Parameters++ 1. **Input Column***: tokenized_text 2. **Topic Column Name**: topic 3. **Number of Vocabularies**: 1000 4. **Number of Topics**: 3 5. **Number of Terminologies**: 3 6. **Iterations**: 20 7. **Learning Method**: Batch 8. **Seed**: 0 9. **Group By**: None ### Python ``` from brightics.function.textanalytics import lda3 input_table = inputs[0] result = lda3(table=input_table, input_col='tokenized_text', topic_name='topic', num_voca=1000, num_topic=3, num_topic_word=3, max_iter=20, learning_method='online', learning_offset=10., random_state=None, group_by=None) output = result['out_table'] ``` In this python script, sample_LatentDirichletAllocation data is used to make topic model and get the result. The result includes assigned topic and contributiveness of each word to assigned topic.
